title: What will be the closing value for the pound against the euro on 1 April 2019?
preds: Considering that the end of this forecast question is very close and that stock shocks in the next 24 hours are extremely unlikely, I update my previous forecast from 95% to a 100% chance, meaning that I am absolutely confident that the closing value for the pound against the euro on 1 April 2019 will be More than €1.10 but less than €1.20.

UPDATE 01.04.2019 After reading some of the other forecasts I decided to adjust accordingly. Indeed, the question will be resolved at 9 am, so it is unlikely that a black swan event will have an significant impact before that, despite being already "in the making".  The probabilities of the boundaries will be changed accordingly to 1% and 2%. As such changes are realistic in the event of a black swan "in the making". However, the difference is justified through the same logic as the last forecast that the current exchange rate is in general closer to the lower than the upper boundary.
Update: current value 1.16. Given the turbulences already endured, it seems impossible that an event will move the pound outside the 1.1-1.2 parameters in the next 24 hours.

Given the ranges here there is virtually 0% chance of the £ will leave the €1.10 to €1.20 range by close of trading on 1 April.
However, the pound will continue it's downturn, likely on at accelerating rate.
My prediction:
1 April: €1.13 ± 0.02
15 April: €1.11 ± 0.03

(Disclaimer: This question is connected to a Brexit at the 29th of March 2019 and its impact on the currencies. The agreed extension of Brexit beyond 29th contradicts with the underlying assumed scenario. Projecting this question on a new Brexit date wouldn’t make sense regarding the aggregation mechanic of this platform). The development of the currency rate over the last month and over the last 6 months don't indicate that there will be a drastic change. The 1% probabilities reflect black swans (with negative outcomes such as a financial crisis or positive outcomes such as discovered untapped oil reserves in the UK: extreme unlikely & high impact). “1.10 € to 1.20 €” is the most likely outcome based on the historical record of the currency rate at question. The options bordering this span are, hence, slightly more likely than the 1% outcomes described above. The option “between €1.00 and €1.10, inclusive” is more likely than “between €1.20 and €1.30, inclusive” due to two reasons: 1) the exchange rate came closer to the lower boundary (11th December 18: 1.1034) than to the upper one (13th March 19: 1,1775) and 2) the exchange rate remained in average closer to the lower boundary than to the upper one (see Bloomberg). As a result, “between €1.00 and €1.10, inclusive” is assessed with a 4% probability and is more likely than “between €1.20 and €1.30, inclusive” with a 2% likelihood by the factor 2. Finally, the option “more than €1.10 but less than €1.20” is the most likely as the currency rate remained within this range for the last 6 months. It is assessed with a 92% probability.   Source: 
Bloomberg (2019):  GBPEUR:CUR GBP-EUR X-RATE: https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPEUR:CUR

As of March 31, the exchange rate of the British Pound to the Euro is 1,16. While there has been some fluctuations during the past months (though the closing value never went below the 1.10 limit, the rate has remained stable during the entire month of March, showing only minor variations. This can be taken as a baserate. (https://www.bbc.com/news/topics/cx250jmk4e7t/pound-sterling-gbp). The House of Commons rejected Theresa May's withdrawal agreement three times, yet this did not affect the rate. Neither did the ecision to extend the deadline for the Uk leaving the EU for that matter. The prime minister's embattled position and the rumours about a revolt in her cabinet failed to have any noticeable effect on the rate as well. Given the political magnitude and far reaching ramifications of these events the chances for the Pound to fall below the 1.10 line in the few remaining hours until April 1 can be considered close to non-existent. Similarly, there is no reason to expect any considerable increase, since the political crisis remains unresolved.  In the short remaining period, even the remote chance of a political earthquake, e.g. sparked by the sudden (and unlikely) resignation of prime minister May is liable to miss  having a major effect on the rate. In my opinion, the only reason why the Pound falling under the 1.10 line or rising above 1.20 cannot be ruled out with absolute certainty stems from the very unlikely although fathomable possibility of a major catastrophic event (In a recent paper Paresh et. al showed for example that terrorist attacks can have both an appreciating and depreciating effect on bilateral exchange rates https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/ecin.12447).

Update: After the rejection of May's withdrawal agreement, for the UK there will be plenty of new possible scenarios developing in the nex weeks, from an hard brexit, to a soft one to a new referendum. In spite of the confusion perceived because of the lack of a clear prospectives of how to act by the Parliament, there hasn't been yet a concrete effective decision (everything is still possible). Also, today the exchange rate is 1,16: I'm confident that this event would not change it over 1.20 or less than 1.10.

Update. Now that the uncertainty surrounding Brexit has been resolved, there shouldn't be any politically induced fluctuations within the next 48 hours. The exchange rate has sat consistently between 1.1 and 1.2 for a while now.

Update: On March 29, 2019, MPs rejected Theresa May's EU withdrawal agreement, meaning the UK missed an EU Deadline, which gave the country the chance to delay Brexit until 22nd of May and leave with a deal. Since the value of pound is still 1,16 against the Euro and such kind of political event wasn't capable of causing fluctuation, we can assume that there won't be any dramatic changes on the 1st of April as well.

Considering that this prognosis is being done just a couple days before closing the question, I am confident that 1 GBP value will stay in a range between 1.10 and 1.20 eur. During the last month, GBP value didn't decrease more than 1.1523 and didn't increase more than 1.775 per euro. As the UK stays in the EU at least until April 12, it doesn't imply any significant changes in the financial markets before then.

Baseline: GBP to EUR Exchange Rate past 5 years; Lowest to highest: 1.0801 - 1.4416 
Brexit referendum was by far the greatest impact in a five year period. Sharp decline from 1.415 to 1.2390. Restabilized to 1.3154, to the lowest turning point mentioned above. Relatively stabilized around 1.123 - 1.1410.
6 months exchange rates show relative incline: 1.1264 - 1.1618, which is interesting. However, this forecast strongly holds that it shall not exceede 1.20, nor shall it dive down below 1.10. 
Baseline holds the forecast in place - even in great Brexit uncertainties. 
Also: closing-gate-insight/hinsight.  Sources: 
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPEUR:CUR
https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/bank-of-england-spot/historical-spot-exchange-rates/gbp/GBP-to-EUR-2017
https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/best-exchange-rates/british-pound-to-euro-exchange-rate-on-2019-03-27
went the wrong way in the last forecast

As of March 29th, the pound is trading at 1.16 Euros. And the uncertainty of the Brexit vote has been depreciating the pound. It did drop yesterday (on Thursday) but has since recovered.
https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/gbp-live-today/11095-pound-sterling-live-on-the-slide-against-euro-and-dollar-as-uncertainty-abounds-ahead-of-third-meaningful-vote However, as of 10:43 (EST) the House rejected the deal, and the pound then dropped to 1.15 Euros. Now there is much uncertainty about if they will extend the deadline to get out of EU by April 12th or if they will try and make another deal which seems very unlikely given how much the House is against May's deal. But by Monday April 1st, it seems that there will be no clear solution in sight, so uncertainty in the pound will continue to grow.

At the time of writing the pound to euro value is 1.16 according to Bloomberg. They also reports the value being between 1.09 - 1.18 for the past 52 weeks. So I expect very large fluctuations to be unlikely giving below 1.00 and more than 1.30 2% probability each. The value reflects underlying demand and it has been rather stable in the past year in spite of all the Brexit uncertainty. Since the UK has been given an extension until April 12th even without an agreement today, I forecast that the value will remain rather stable until at least April 1st. 
Currency values are not only determined by political events and this causes irreducible uncertainty regarding the value. For this reason I have put 10% probability in both the 1.00-1.10 and 1.20-1.30 bracket.

As of March 28, the British pound is trading at 1,16 Euros. Hence, the number represents the baseline for the forecast. As the worst exchange rate was 1.1004 on August, 28, 2018, we shouldn't expect dramatic change within 3 days and it going below €1.00. Besides, the uncertainty around the "no-deal" alternative hasn't caused an extreme instability of the currency during the last several months and the exchange rate has been fluctuating between 1.1031-1.1764 since September 2018, being somewhat stable between 1.330-1764 since mid-February of 2019.  Furthermore, since the EU has granted article 50 an extension until the 12th of April at least, there is high likelihood of the exchange rate to be between €1.10-1.20 on April 1, 2019. On March 29 2019, the UK Parliament will vote on Theresa May's Brexit deal for the third time and it is confirmed to be the last time as well.  We've seen how different political events have affected the pound within the last 3 years. For example, the discussion of putting Brexit on hold, boosted the pound. On the contrary, triggering the article 50 had a negative impact on the pound. Therefore, it is convenient to assume that tomorrow will have a significant importance for the further development of the value of the pound. It needs to be noted that May's deal still has strong opposition in the Parliament and the scenario of it passing is described as "parliamentary miracle" to emphasise the low probability of it. We can consider the final "no-deal" decision as a negative impact on the exchange rate and, therefore, cannot exclude the chance of it being between €1.00-1.10 on April 1, 2019.

The implications of political decisions on currency exchange rates are empirically evident. One famose example is the decision of the US to invade Iraq in 2003. Immediately after the decision's announcement, the US Dollar lost 14% against the Euro. (https://moneytransfercomparison.com/major-economical-events-which-impacted-currency-rates/) Turning to Brexit and the question of an appropriate baseline in order to estimate the closing value of the Pound against the Euro on April, 1, it gets complicated due to the fact that the UK is the first country to leave the EU, the world's biggest and most intertwined economic trade block. However, due to the fact that the Brexit process has been going on for quite a while now with several major incidents, such as the decision of the referendum itself, a lost general election for the British prime minister Theresa May, or the rejection of May's deal in the parliament (twice), it makes sense to take a look at the development of the exchange rates throughout this period: - 2019 Low: 1.106 - High: 1.1507
- 2018 Low: 1.1023 - High: 1.1591
- 2017 Low: 1.0771 - High 1.1957
https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/bank-of-england-spot/historical-spot-exchange-rates/gbp/GBP-to-EUR-2017 So only once in August 2017 the pound went under 1.10 against the Euro throughout the whole Brexit process. Due to the most probable postponement of the Brexit (or an acceptance of May's deal and an exit of the UK on time, which would probably rather stabilize the pound rather than weaken it due to deterring a no deal Brexit from happen - the economy biggest fear), the forecast at hand assumes that the trend will most likely continue and there will be no major variation from yesterday's value (On March, 27 the value for the pound against the euro closed at 1 against 1.1688 (https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/best-exchange-rates/british-pound-to-euro-exchange-rate-on-2019-03-27)). Thus, the forecast at hand estimates a likelihood of 96% that the Pound will close as of more than 1.10€ but less than 1.20€ on April 1. Due to the high degree in the context of Brexit, no option is ruled out completley by the forecast at hand. Thus,  all other options are given a 1% chance to realize.

A resolution that’s bullish enough to push the pound that high doesn’t seems possible this week. Uncertainty is likely to continue and that will likely keep the pound range bound. Ex-post edit: A lesson from this question is that, though as people we are often overconfident, in some cases, such as this one, we can be under-confident (as demonstrated by the crowd forecasts on this question). In the current news environment, it's tempting to see Brexit as the one factor that has outsized influence over the UK economy and currency. Availability bias would lead one to then overestimate its influence and to predict that the currency's future is very uncertain due to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit. But this ignores the historical base rates that suggested that the currency was far more stable than assumed by the crowd. This speaks to the usefulness of quantitative methods that estimate uncertainty such as the Monte Carlo method I used. Such methods often tell us that there is far more uncertainty than we typically anticipate. This often leads people to throw their hands up and say something to the effect of "well, great, things are very uncertain, but we still don't know how to act on this information". This case illustrates the usefulness of these methods as ways of saying *how much* uncertainty there is.
Just a couple days left so going all in.

Baseline 1.17 € as of 27.03.18.  It is a fact that Brexit does not happen at least until the 12th of April. The prices have been stable between 1,10 and 1,20 since midsommer 2016 until now with only few episodes under 1,10 in late summer of 2017.

Update: in the last week the GBP has been at  a low of 1.147 and a high of 1.175 approximately -- still well within the parameters of 1.1 and 1.2. Given the extension's reduction of short-term uncertainty and the fact that the GBP has not gone beyond or below these values in the last year, it is considered more likely still that it remain within these values on April 1 (95%).  The % allocated to either side of this option are provided to account for an unforeseen event with the potential to radically implicate the financial market.
<= 0.2% prob of breaching £1.20 over next 4 trading days.
Parliament's move is pushing the price higher. https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-sterling/pound-strengthens-on-hints-of-support-for-pm-mays-brexit-deal-idUSKCN1R70W9
Update to reflect most recent rates. Rate has continued to sit between the 1.10-1.20 bracket, making it the most likely outcome, despite uncertainty of brexit.

The £ fluctuations seem to have been following the political variations of the Brexit. Today, (March 25th) the £ is valued at 1.1645€. Last year, when the Brexit discussions were facing the highest levels of uncertainty, the £ remained between the interval of 1.10€ and 1.20€. In that sense, and taking into account today’s value plus the latest discussions between May and Bruxelles on potential extension dates (meaning a lower level of uncertainty on the market today), I expect the £ to be remaining between 1.10€ and 1.20€ in the next days, furthermore considering that the Brexit case will not experience an upheaval this week  https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPEUR:CUR

If we look at the behavior of the Pound in relation to the Euro currency since the beginning of 2019, we can notice that it has actually been swinging quite often, ranging from an exchange rate of 1,1 to 1,18. This is clearly the result of the several twists during the Brexit talks, especially the double rejection of May’s deal by the British Parliament.  However, the recent developments and the following extension of Brexit deadline to at least April 12 (most likely May 22) makes now this forecast much easier than before (as a matter of fact, I predicted this exact Brexit outcome in other 2 related forecasts). Therefore, since currently the exchange rate it is at 1.1688, from here to April 1 it is highly probable that it will remain between 1.10 and 1.20. Usually, I do not like to be overconfident, but in this case I believe it is right to assess to this outcome a 95% chance.  Considering that it did not happen even in the last months when the situation was much more uncertain, the likelihood for the pound to fall below 1 euro is 0%. The same it is true for its rising above 1,3.  Regarding the remining 2 possibilities (between €1.00 and €1.10 inclusive and between €1.20 and €1.30 inclusive) I cannot totally exclude them since we live in what Knight would have defined as an “uncertain world” and that the Brexit outcome has been strongly uncertain since its very beginning. In this sense, for instance, a sudden resignation of PM T. May (very unlikely but still possible) might actually lead to a considerable variation of the Euro-Pound exchange rate. That said, in case it would be more likely to be between €1.00 and €1.10 inclusive than between €1.20 and €1.30 since the Pound is currently just slightly above 1.00 (1.16). Sources:
-https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/data/currencies/gbp-pairs/GBPEUR-exchange-rate
-https://www.cnbc.com/2019/01/16/brexit-dont-buy-british-pound-sterling-investment-experts-say.html
-https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPEUR:CUR

Update: the announcement that Article 50 will be extended to May 22 (if May's withdrawal agreement is accepted next week) or April 12 (if it is not) will remove much short-term uncertainty in the markets. The value of the pound is therefore not expected to experience dramatic fluctuations outside the parameters of which it has remained in the last year (1.1-1.2).
Surrounded by Brexit nonsense - breakthrough unlikely there, the market likely moving sideways the rest of the period. More betting than forecasting bias?

Today, 21st March 2019, 1£ = 1.15€
In 2016, before the Brexit referendum, the exchange rate was around 1 pound = 1.25/1.3 €; while on 26th of June 2016 (3 days after the Brexit) the value of the pound fell drastically from 1.31 to 1.2. For the rest of 2016 it remains between 1.1 and 1.2.
In 2017 the exchange rate has reached a minimum level of 1.075 and a maximum of 1,1955€.
In 2018 there wasn’t a huge difference: the average of the exchange rate has been 1£ = 1.1303€, with a maximum of 1.1578 and a minimum of 1.1004 (but always >1.1€).
Since the beginning of the 2019 the value of 1 £ has changed between 1,1€ and 1,18€, without ever reaching 1,2€. So, from the statistics, we should exclude the possibility of an exchange rate under 1€, focusing on the other possibilities.
The last three months have been a critical period for Great Britain, with the Parliament rejecting twice the agreement reached between the premier May and the EU about a soft Brexit, plus the pressures of the ultimate date to take a decision (29 of March) and the internal fights in the party at the government. All these factors have an impact on the markets, but in the last years they have never had an effect that brought to have an exchange rate higher than 1.2 (excluded). Also, one week ago the British Parliament has approved the delay of the Brexit until the 30th of June, which could make the market stable until that day, because there won’t be yet an official Brexit. Still, I’m sure the pound will remain weak but sticking between 1.10 and 1.20€. 
However, because the markets are unpredictable, we cannot exclude completely the possibility of a higher loss for the GBP. Also, the EU has still to accept or not the extension of the art.50 (hard Brexit is still theoretically possible). These reasons make me set some possibilities for the first and the second options.
Random Walk model suggests 99.9, 0.1 split between current bucket and >1.2x<1.3 bucket. Adjusting to account for possible rally from expected Brexit resolution.
Effective selling/supply in 1.17s + remaining momentum rollover (ROC7), slam the door shut on 1.20+. http://schrts.co/DERVbsQA

As of March 21, 1 pound is worth 1.1533 euros. This value ranged between 1.0981 and 1.1803 in the last 52 weeks, therefore within the boundaries of the third option (except for a short amount of time and value).  The closing value will obviously depend on Brexit. However, with only 10 days to the end of the forecast, and with Brexit probably being delayed by extending article 50 until the 30 June, it is highly unlikely for any major change in the value to occur before then. Nevertheless, since markets can be highly unpredictable, and since a hard Brexit is still theoretically possible, I will give some chances also for the first two options.

In the last year, the Pound Sterling (GBP) has fluctuated between a low of 1.1028 and a high of 1.173 against the Euro. The GBP seems to respond to Brexit developments. Uncertainty has correlated with a decline in value, and the opposite is true when the future appears to be more stable. For example, the aforementioned high was reached on March 14, 2019 — the day in which the Commons voted to allow May to request permission to extend — in response to increased knowledge of the state of the market in the near future (one where the UK is unlikely to leave the EU on March 29). On April 1, whether an extension has been granted will be known. So too, will the length of that extension if granted. This is likely to stabilise the market — no matter the outcome, since the market prefers to operate in the known. It is unforeseeable that the GBP will reach a value outside the 1.1-1.2 parameter, as it has not done in the last year and the greater certainty surrounding Brexit on April should reduce major anomalies. Thus this is forecasted at 80%. An equal chance of 10% is given to either side of this parameter accounting for the chance a boom resulting from a stabilisation, or a serious fall resulting from an unexpected hard Brexit.

GBP price against the Euro on March 19, 2019: 1.17 GBP = 1 euro
More uncertainty = a weaker currency than other currencies
Indeed, on 27 June 2016 after the vote in favor of a UK exit from the EU, the pound fell to 83.26 pence for one euro, a bad presage.
Since November 2015, the pound fell sharply from 1.43 for 1 euro on November 27, 2015, to 1.17 on November 25, 2016, after the vote.
Since 2016, the pound has stagnated around 1.15 on average until now.
It is therefore in a low position, and the great uncertainty that the Brexit will bring by April 1, 2019 will not tend to increase certainly. It must therefore be known that the British political evolution will be inseparably linked to the evolution of the pound, and that Brexit will therefore be the catalyst of the value of the pound.
According to the different scenarios of Brexit, we can try to understand the possible value of pound against the euro :
- In the case of the extension of the Brexit deadline, the value of the pound will not have to change so much and therefore be between 1.10 and 1.20. Or even in the case of a finely played Brexit soft, go up a little more than the average of the last two years. Moreover, this Brexit scenario seems the most likely (in a forecast I place it at 65%).
- In the case of Parliament's adoption of the Brexit agreement, the pound is expected to fall but still stabilize thanks to agreements with the European Union. The likelihood of this scenario is 20% in my opinion. The fall will not be too brutal.
In case of No-Deal, depreciation of the currency will be extremely strong. Indeed, imports will be much cheaper against UK exports, which will be taxed by the EU. In this case, the scenario for the pound is not impossible to be below the 1.0 value bar. Nevertheless, the likelihood of this scenario at present is 10%.
It is therefore more likely, following the current Brexit events, that the pound will be between 1.10 and 1.20 for 1.0 euro on 1 April 2019. However, the great uncertainty of this event does not exclude in any case an average decline in the price, or a very sharp drop in case of No-Deal, which is not out of the odds, even if it is less possible.

My forecast takes its move from a set of considerations.
First, cutting the extremes. For the pound to fall below 1 euro or rising above 1,3 is absolutely unlikely. Even though the possible enter into effect of the Brexit could have a major impact on pund's value, these two extreme cases are, in my opinion, almost impossible.
The other considerations necessarlly have to take into account the major economic and politic dynamics that can happen in the next month in Europe and UK - namely, most of all the path the Brexit will take. While in this forecast I won't analyze in lenght all the possibilities, here I reduce the analysis to economic matters - not exactely my field, but it's worth a shot. The resilience of the pound, even in the most turbolent phases of UK politics since 2017, is definetly something to take into account. UK is and will remain a big economy, which in my opinion will be affected by the turbolence deriving from Brexit but not necessarily in a catastrophic way. Moreover, a macroeconomic dynamic has to be taken into account: while the effects of the Brexit could lower the pound's value, the expenses deriving from the deal - if the deal remains the one stipulated, which is debatable, the UK will have to pay around 36 billions to the EU - will produce a reduction in the availabilty of pounds on the currency market, which in macroeconomics means an increase in the pound's value. If the UK's export, on the other side, will suffer for the exit from the EU, this would lead to a decrease in the pound's value to compensate the exports' reduction. All in all, wether the Brexit will be delayed (which would lead to a more or less stability in the exchange rate) or the Brexit will happen the 29th of this month the pound will be stable. In the even of a no deal, the pound could depreciate slightly (20% to the second option)

Here is my potentially sorry attempt at using Bayes theorem to update my previous prediction. After the recent votes against a no deal Brexit (https://www.vox.com/world/2019/3/14/18265393/brexit-vote-second-referendum-parliament), and a vote to postpone the withdrawal date (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/14/world/europe/brexit-vote-amendment-referendum.html), I'm making a Bayesian inference in assuming the Pound is more likely to hold steady now that it seems unlikely March 29th will be the withdrawal date. My conditional is that Brexit happens, which GJP predicts has a 26% chance. I previously measured the probability of the pound at more than 1.20 Euro at 5%, which now falls to roughly 2% using Bayes theorem. I put 0% on below 1 and more than 1.30 Euro due to Bayesian math not changing existing 0% or 100% predictions. With the chance of a false conditional applied to the remaining categories, I redistributed the remaining value to the pound ending at a value between 1.10 and 1.20 Euro, and 1.00 and 1.10 Euro.

In the last year, the lower boundary of the exchange rate was 1.10060 (in august) whereas the highest boundary is where it is in the last few days at 1.175. This is a difference of 0.075 Predicting for the closing exchange rate on 1st of april means a little over 3 days to recover from the Brexit shock that is likely to occur on the 29th of March.  On the day of the brexit vote, The rate was at 1.31080, and in the 3 days after it dropped to 1.20135. This is a drop of 0.11 in three days post the initial brexit shock.  I believe that, having grown accustomed to the idea of a brexit, the days after 29th of March will not see as much volatility as the three days after the brexit vote. Especially not considering that the 29th of March will likely mean that the brexit deal negotiations will be extended.  The one way I do see a similar shock to the exchange rate is if the UK leaves the EU without a deal, the so called hard brexit. The house has voted that there will be no hard Brexit by the British, but a hard brexit can still be enforced by European nations, which therefore does not rule out the possibility of such an exit. In that case it would be possible to see the exchange rate plummet below the 1.10 boundary.  There is a small chance, either due to the extension of the article 50, or because of a deal being striken, that there is an upwards shock that would lift the exhange rates above 1.20. However I do not believe an extension of the article 50 will give rise to a rise significant enough to allow it to go above the 1.20 boundary, because an extension does not clear up any uncertainty regarding the brexit in the long term.
Not sure why people bullish on quid. Extension is just extending chaos. Acknowledge potential 1,2-1,3 range however.
Outside view as reflected in my random walk model suggests 92-8, but I continue to raise the odds of >1.2 due to the Inside View that a likely extension of Article 50 will be bullish for the pound.

Since the 2016 Brexit vote, the Sterling Pound has been weakened as its value relative to other currencies has declined. It seems that declines are most heavily associated with times of insecurity. E.g. the pound dropped in Nov. 2018 in the wake of the minister resignations that followed May’s deal.  Interestingly enough, the pound experienced an increase after the vote on March 12th, where May’s deal was voted down once again. This could be an indication that the markets believe that an extension of article 50 is ahead and the realization of a hard Brexit is pushed back (https://www.poundsterlinglive.com/gbp-live-today/11023-may-loses-vote-pound-sterling-in-relief-bounce-vs-euro-and-dollar). Tonight’s vote (March 13th) will likely influence the pound also, either negatively in the case of a hard Brexit or positively if the UK’s crash-out of the EU is, temporarily, avoided.  Since the Brexit referendum, the lowest level of the Pound against the Euro has been €1.11. Prior to Brexit is was above €1.30. The past year has seen the pound value fluctuate between €1.11-1.16 (https://www.ig.com/uk/financial-events/brexit/value-of-the-pound-since-brexit). Should tomorrow's vote see cabinet decide on a hard Brexit, the pound could plummet below €1.11. However, most likely cabinet will vote against the hard Brexit. In this case, the pound could increase, but likely not above €1.20 as the future of the UK’s way out of the EU is still very uncertain.

May’s deal seems less likely to pass. An extension of A50 appears more likely than it did yesterday. I am operating under the theory that a passage of May’s deal would be very bullish while an extension would be moderately bullish.

Considering the uncertainty that still surround the Brexit deal, but also taking into account that the Pound has remained very resilient over the last 2,5 years. Even though it declined quite a lot following the vote in 2016, it has remained at a stable level since, slowly declining. However over the last months it has seen somewhat of an increase, therefore I have chosen to give 'between €1.20 and €1.30, inclusive', a slight higher percentage, compared to 'More than €1.10 but less than €1.20' Source: https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPEUR:CUR

When learning the mechanics of GJ Open, I made a practice prediction on the UK rate to the Euro. Since then, I have decided to reevaluate my previous prediction and use those judgements as a baseline for using Bayes Theorem. First, the below 1 Euro and above 1.30 Euro I gave a 0% chance, so neither will be used as Bayesian mathematics doesn’t change already existing 0% or 100% predictions.
	First, I gave a 10% chance of the Pound being above 1.20 Euro. I made this based on the assumption that the UK pulled off Brexit successfully (which is my conditional). Currently, GJ Open says that there is a 26% chance of this happening. When Bayes Theorem is applied, it now gives  a 3.76% chance.
	Since I applied the possibility of a false conditional to both by 1-1.10 Euro percentage and 1.10-1.20 Euro percentage, I then proportionally redistributed the reduced chance of ending above 1.20 to these other categories.

As the tentative withdrawal date for the UK is March 29, I looked at the rate the pound fell when the Brexit vote happened, dropping from about 1.3 to 1.17 in a week, and it hasn't peaked above 1.16 since.  I think its fair to say we can expect a fairly similar drop as its hard to say whether or not Brexit will go through as planned as the Tories seem to have expended quite a fair amount of political capital in their failed proposal.

Latest Random walk simulations suggest 0, 0, 94, 6, 0. But I am adjusting higher on the chance that the likely extension of Article 50 leads to bullishness in the pound as it seems to already have raised the price a little.

The Eurozone flash inflation & unemployment figures for February will be released on Friday. A lower than forecast inflation figure would cause the ECB to consider delaying the expected interest rate hikes, which would in turn cause the EUR to fall, thus pushing GBP-EUR exchange rate nearer the €1.20 to €1.30 bucket. A higher than expected figure would have the opposite effect, but because we are currently at 1.1705 there's a very big buffer before we get close to the €1.00 to €1.10 bucket. This question closes the same day that the Eurozone inflation figures for March are due to be published.

Although Brexit may alter the puns against the euro in the closing date, I don’t think it will be altered significantly. I have also forecasts that the £ against the euro would not exceeded more than $1.30. I think the effects of Brexit will possibly alter the conversions as the relationship between the country’s have been effected which could cause for a slight decrease in the conversions between the £ and €.

Expect continued uncertainty around Brexit outcome and loss of confidence in politicians handling of the process to affect rates beyond 1 April. It looks increasingly like the Brexit process will be delayed or subject to a second vote. Large businesses vocalising concerns or impact and media scaremongering about impact of no deal or disorderly Brexit will further undermine confidence.

Current rate 1.158. Future limits for March and April 1.127 and 1.181. This is the starting point. 
FX rate will be subject to Brexit outcome. Options:
- Amended deal is approved. At a first view, it seems unlikely as minor amendments have been included so far, but if leavers understand that procedures to force extension might be passed, they could support it (am I thinking straight?). In this case, rate keeps as expected as reduced uncertainty. 30%.
- Amended deal is not approved, but changes in parliament procedures pass and force an extension, removing the no-deal option. Probably coming together with snap election or second Brexit election. Most likely scenario, with a minor depreciation of the pound which could be slightly over or under the 1.10. 45% of less than 5% drop, or just 1.10...  and 5% over 5%.
- Leave with no-deal option on March 29th, total uncertainty, more than 10% drop. 10%.
- Just the door open for other options, but very unlikely.

We are in very unpredictable times and I have minimal skill. In general, expertise performs badly in these situations too. The first question I need to answer is: will any amount of research I can do allow me to out perform the market.  Although I don't agree that markets are perfectly efficient they are closer to a random walk than a predictable trend. If "the crowd" believed that Euros would be more valuable on 1st of April than today anyone with spare money or who could borrow it should buy Euros today, the demand would go up leading to price going up, until the price is marginally lower than the expected price on that day. The fact that the price of a Euro now is 86p suggests that the best guess as to the price of euros on 1st April is 86p. I have allowed for wide variation in price given the unlikeness of anyone government to intervene to a heroic degree to interfere with market forces.
I'm expecting Brexit date being postponed, with pound not crashing as it would do with 'no deal'.
Not drastically dropping from current value

@michalbod makes a great point that Brexit affects both the GBP and the EUR. Such correlation implies that the GBP-EUR rate is more stable than I previously assumed (which is consistent with historical data and my Random Walk/Monte Carlo model).

Today's spot is 1.15; trailing 3m trading range is really tight and well within 1.10-1.20. There is some chance of Brexit-related changes in the exchange rate before the deadline, which I am assuming will favor EUR over GBP.

Because I think parliament will fudge some kind of deal which will cause the £ to go up a bit but there is still a pretty good chance of delay which I think won't make a huge impact and some chance of no deal which will push the price down
Whilst Brexit uncertainty remains believe that deadline will be extended after March 29 so that markets will not radically change position.

Am I only one who has hard time to switch mind to think GBP as base currency in EUR - GBP pair? In questions like this I often use similar approach as @Emil or @nigster  but I am going to refrain from it this time. I believe Brexit is  really one off event that will determine final result so using past data is not adding much value here..
So different Brexit scenarios will lead to different buckets. What I see is that general opinion is that Article 50 will be extended that would lead to GBP appreciating or staying in current bucket but I am still not that optimistic about it. UK MPs are going to instruct the government to extend the article 50 negotiating period until the end of the year if the prime minister fails to win parliamentary approval for a withdrawal Bill by February 26th, but Extension needs to be approved by EU unanimously as well. EU insisted many times that to extend Article 50 it needs to have good reason like new referendum, probably another elections would also work but I do not believe those are options British parliament would accept? What are chances that British Parliament will agree to ANY reason why it should be extended? 
I can see EU accepting extension even if the reason is just better preparation for no deal Brexit but I do not see British parliament agreeing for it.
And if the deal is extended, option that as written above is hard to achieve in my opinion,  I think that after short term euphoria resulting in GBP appreciating everyone will realize that problems are not fixed. Can was just kicked dawn the road.  As a result GBPEUR will probably stay in current 1.1-1.2 bucket which is quite wide. No deal Brexit, option that is still probable in my opinion will lead to depreciation of GBP but will it fall below 1.1? There are chances but it may as well stay in 1.1-1.15 area as EUR will get harm for no deal Brexit as well. Therefore movement on GBP/USD would be more significant than  EUR/GBP. 
What are other factors that may impact result. I do not see any rate hikes neither by BOE or ECB. 
Maybe some other debt crisis inside EU but time frame is relatively short so probabilities of such event are slim and as I wrote above key question is Brexit outcome.

Outside view:  First, I use base rate information in the form of historical standard deviation of daily % change in the price from the past 20 years [1]. I use this information to build a Monte Carlo model that creates many future possible scenarios for the next 47 trading days and I tabulate the frequencies of the respective buckets. The model is described in my BTC forecast [2].  Results:
0, 10, 77, 13, 0 Inside view:  The effects of Brexit will very possibly result in a deviation from historical base rates. A hard exit will lead to further devaluation and vice versa. The outcome will depend on what is expected and priced in the markets currently, which I will address in a future post.  For now, I see the recent unravelling of May's deal as a low point. Any improvements that lower the chances of a hard Brexit will likely strengthen the GBP. To watch:
Next week's withdrawal agreement vote [3]
Any further rumors and discussions about a General Election in the short term. [1] https://www.macrotrends.net/2553/euro-british-pound-exchange-rate-historical-chart
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/816322
[3] https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/explainers/parliament-meaningful-vote-brexit Curious about @dsarin's, @nigster's and others' views.

The base rate using data from 2000 to today is (0% - 9% - 85% - 5% - 0%). But since we are in eventful moment for the GBP/EUR pair, my guess is that the volatility will be higher than normal, so the probability in the tails should be higher.
